instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.D7010: What is D7010? Diode between ground and gate of Q7010 on 2013-2015 year retina model macbook pros, necessary for Q7010 to allow PPDCIN_G3H to flow through to PP3V42_G3H power supply input. When this diode dies or corrodes, PP3V42_G3H input will not have any voltage, and chargers will not turn on. This can often be the problem if a system only works with a knockoff charger/bench power supply. .
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message:
Hi,

I get no green light on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
ISL area looks perfect for ref.

On <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> i get 0.02v on pin 1 which should be 16v+
Likewise for pin 2 its 0v.

On <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> i do get voltage on pin 1 at 16v but I'm confused what the DCIN ISOL area is for and whether this is causing the issue?

Any ideas?

Thanks

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Update: Ran a wire from pin 1 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7020</TRANSISTOR> to pin 1 <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> and i get a green light and PP3V42 obviously now present.... still not powering on though. Will pick this up again in the morning

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: First start with powering a magsafe connector with an external PSU or use a fake Chinese charger. The original ones will shut down if anything is wrong and are no good for diagnosis. Voltage on <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR> is the first thing to measure then.

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Okay will do that later on - also forgot to add that <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> was actually missing altogether. Do you think this is causing the problem?

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: okay so without the wire on <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR> i get 16.3v on each side

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: replaced <DIODE>D7010</DIODE> and i now have a light on the charger. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> so will troubleshoot <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: missing <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> :( any ideas of common areas for this to fail? I have 41k on the clock signal. Is this too high?

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Is it entirely missing or does it pulse for a second when charger is plugged in?

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Are you using a 60W/85W charger, these will not power on from 45W!

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Yes 85W from the PSU. Louis I will check if it pulses when Iâ€™m back at the office. Thanks!

threads.title: [SOLVED] No green light <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
threads.message: Okay back on it - swapped out the cables for the PSU as they were getting old anyway. Powered on straight away..... thanks for the help as always!
